item.title: Fallout Season 2 Filming Delayed By Massive LA Fires
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/fallout-tv-show-la-wildfire-fires-california-season-2-1851735652

Filming on the next season of Amazon and Bethesda’s popular Fallout TV show has been delayed due to the ongoing and massive fires near Los Angeles, California.

Suggested Reading

Live Forever in the Universe of 'New World: Aeternum'

Suggested Reading

On January 7, Deadline reported that production and filming on Fallout’s second season was set to begin on January 8. The production had paused for a holiday break and was set to start back up on that day. However, the large fires affecting Southern California and the greater Los Angeles area have caused a delay. It’s now reported that the plan is to start filming again on February 10, though that might change depending on the fires and the weather.

Fallout’s first season arrived to critical acclaim in April 2024. The series is based on the hit games from Bethesda, and just a few weeks after it premiered, it was picked up for a second season.

As spotted by GameSpot, FilmLA—the agency responsible for all film permits in Los Angeles—has warned that resources normally available to film and TV productions in the area would not be accessible due to the horrible fires which have destroyed hundreds of homes and other buildings and killed at least two people. The LA County Fire Department has also withdrawn all filming permits in areas affected by or near the fire.

Variety reports that production has been stopped on other TV shows, including Abbott Elementary, Grey’s Anatomy, Hacks, and Suits LA. Even in cases where a production’s sets or soundstages may not be directly threatened by the fires, the smoke and ash are dangerous to breathe, and these delays are intended to protect cast and crew. Universal Studios has also shut down to protect guests, employees, and crew members.

Since Tuesday, major fires have burned over 10,000 acres of Southern California, forcing many to flee their homes for safety. One of these fires is already the most destructive wildfire in LA history, and one early estimate says the fires have already caused over $5o billion in damages. Firefighters from other states, including Oregon, are rushing to California to help contain the devastating blaze.

.

item.title: Absolute Unit Jack Reacher Encounters An Even Bigger Dude In Season 3
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/jack-reacher-season-3-amazon-prime-trailer-date-1851735600

Reacher is a crime show about a big guy solving big mysteries, usually with his big muscles. It’s won hearts and minds thanks to remaining laser-focused on this simple but laudable premise, and season 3 appears to be doubling down on it in its new trailer as gentle giant Jack Reacher faces off against a dude who’s even bigger.

Suggested Reading

Live Forever in the Universe of 'New World: Aeternum'

Suggested Reading

Reacher season 3 arrives on Amazon Prime Video beginning with three episodes on February 20 that see the retired U.S. Army major going undercover to investigate a rug import business that’s seemingly up to no good, smuggling guns, drugs, or some other illicit product. It’s on this latest assignment that Reacher faces his toughest challenge yet: a 7-foot-tall bodyguard named Paulie. “He’s twice my size,” Reacher tells his handler. Yes...ha ha ha...YES.

Fans are already ecstatic. “Somebody is bigger than Reacher. This alone is a solid reason to watch Season 3,” reads the top comment on the season 3 trailer’s YouTube page. “Finally, a worthy opponent for Reacher! This deserves unlimited seasons, keep em coming!” reads another. “This show should go on for 30 seasons,” added a third.

Reacher’s success is part of a recent wave of “lean back” TV, also known as “smart-dumb” TV, that indulges in the fun and satisfying delights of storytelling that knows what it’s about, does it very well, and doesn’t try to take itself too seriously. Where The Lincoln Lawyer revels in absurd but totally awesome courtroom antics, Reacher in unabashedly a show about a decent, stand-up guy who never found a bad situation that couldn’t be made right again through the careful deployment of his rippling biceps and manhole-cover quads.

In season 2 he threw a grill at a guy. I can’t wait to see what he picks up in season 3.

.
